issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw: Hi do you mind posting a screenshot of your TF tree? You can visualize it using `rosrun rqt_tf_tree rqt_tf_tree` . Also, could you tell us the frame in which your lidar pointcloud is reporting in? You can check this by running `rostopic echo \{LIDAR_TOPIC} --noarr -n1` where \{LIDAR\_TOPIC\} is your lidar topic, something like `/wamv/sensors/lidar/points` . There should be a field called `frame_id` in the message.
content.html: Hi do you mind posting a screenshot of your TF tree? You can visualize it using rosrun rqt_tf_tree rqt_tf_tree . Also, could you tell us the frame in which your lidar pointcloud is reporting in? You can check this by running rostopic echo \{LIDAR_TOPIC} --noarr -n1 where {LIDAR_TOPIC} is your lidar topic, something like /wamv/sensors/lidar/points . There should be a field called frame_id in the message.

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
Hi. I am facing the same issue when running the rviz tutorial with: ` roslaunch vrx_gazebo vrx.launch camera_enabled:=true gps_enabled:=true imu_enabled:=true `and `roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization_example.launch` .

Picture of the TF tree:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3959183491-Screenshot_from_2020-04-22_13-29-03.png)
_\(had to use a screenshot as the picture from the rqt\_tf\_tree was too large\)_

I notice that it is not any node for imu\_link in the tree. 

‌

Output from `rostopic echo \/wamv/sensors/lidars/lidar_wamv/points --noarr -n1` : 

```
header: 
  seq: 798
  stamp: 
    secs: 1092
    nsecs: 499000000
  frame_id: "wamv/lidar_wamv_link"
height: 1
width: 4974
fields: "<array type: sensor_msgs/PointField, length: 5>"
is_bigendian: False
point_step: 32
row_step: 159168
data: "<array type: uint8, length: 159168>"
is_dense: True
---
```

Output from `rostopic echo \/wamv/sensors/imu/imu/data --noarr -n1` :

```
header: 
  seq: 16641
  stamp: 
    secs: 1109
    nsecs: 600000000
  frame_id: "wamv/imu_wamv_link"
orientation: 
  x: -0.00433029055839
  y: -0.000363454619484
  z: -0.981755292307
  w: 0.190099086037
orientation_covariance: "<array type: float64[9, length: 9>"
angular_velocity: 
  x: 0.00191322878219
  y: 0.00500619084159
  z: -2.50860551799e-05
angular_velocity_covariance: "<array type: float64[9, length: 9>"
linear_acceleration: 
  x: 0.0625340611251
  y: -0.0107383665749
  z: 9.76237011877
linear_acceleration_covariance: "<array type: float64[9, length: 9>"
---
```

‌

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
It is strange that the TF tree is broken from utm to base\_link. This has to do with the robot\_localization configuration file. Also the IMU seems to be missing from the TF tree but you are somehow getting IMU data.

‌

Regardless, you should still be able to view the raw lidar points in your own local frame in RVIZ. Could you attach a screenshot of RVIZ with the pointcloud2 view enabled for the lidar? Make sure the top left setting in RVIZ under `global setting` called `fixed frame` is set to `wamv/base_link` .
content.html:
It is strange that the TF tree is broken from utm to base_link. This has to do with the robot_localization configuration file. Also the IMU seems to be missing from the TF tree but you are somehow getting IMU data.

‌

Regardless, you should still be able to view the raw lidar points in your own local frame in RVIZ. Could you attach a screenshot of RVIZ with the pointcloud2 view enabled for the lidar? Make sure the top left setting in RVIZ under global setting called fixed frame is set to wamv/base_link .

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
You are correct. I am able to view the lidar points in the local frame \(base\_link\). 

Here you can see the errors and warnings when displaying the base\_link. 

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/1841363039-screenshotRviz1.png)
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3538487618-screenshotRviz2.png)
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/422903679-screenshotRviz3.png)
‌
content.html:
You are correct. I am able to view the lidar points in the local frame (base_link).

Here you can see the errors and warnings when displaying the base_link.

‌

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
I finally realized what could be the possible source of error. If you look at [pull request 216](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/216/fix-issue-188/diff), you can see that generation of URDF from the yaml file format has changed for the GPS and IMU sensor. As such, even my old custom URDF build was no longer working but all I had to do was regenerate the URDF based on the command provided in the [generating URDF tutorial](#!/osrf/vrx/wiki/tutorials/Creating%20a%20custom%20WAM-V%20Thruster%20and%20Sensor%20Configuration%20For%20Competition). For simplicity, I have included the relevant command for you:  

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo generate_wamv.launch thruster_yaml:=$HOME/my_wamv/thruster_config.yaml sensor_yaml:=$HOME/my_wamv/sensor_config.yaml wamv_target:=$HOME/my_wamv/my_wamv.urdf
```

‌

Hopefully this resolves the error for you.
content.html:
I finally realized what could be the possible source of error. If you look at pull request 216, you can see that generation of URDF from the yaml file format has changed for the GPS and IMU sensor. As such, even my old custom URDF build was no longer working but all I had to do was regenerate the URDF based on the command provided in the generating URDF tutorial. For simplicity, I have included the relevant command for you: 

roslaunch vrx_gazebo generate_wamv.launch thruster_yaml:=$HOME/my_wamv/thruster_config.yaml sensor_yaml:=$HOME/my_wamv/sensor_config.yaml wamv_target:=$HOME/my_wamv/my_wamv.urdf

‌

Hopefully this resolves the error for you.

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
Ok then in that case the fix should be simple. Previously,  in the `localization_example.launch` , the static TFs are published via

```
<!-- Publishes static transforms (gps, imu, cameras, etc) to /tf -->
  <node ns="wamv" pkg="robot_state_publisher" type="robot_state_publisher" name="rob_st_pub">
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="wamv" />
  </node>
```

However, as seen in [pull request 216](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/216/fix-issue-188/diff), revolute joints are being used instead of fixed joints. The robot\_state\_publisher can only publish static joint TF to my knowledge. As such, you will need to use the `joint_state_publisher` as well to get the GPS as IMU TFs to be published. You can try this instead:

‌

‌

```
<!-- Publishes fixed joint static transforms (cameras, lidars, etc) to /tf -->
  <node ns="wamv" pkg="robot_state_publisher" type="robot_state_publisher" name="rob_st_pub">
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="wamv" />
  </node>

<!-- Publishes revolute joint static transforms (gps and imu) to /tf -->
    <node name="joint_state_publisher" pkg="joint_state_publisher" type="joint_state_publisher" output="screen">
      <param name="gui" value="false" />
    </node>
```

‌

I don’t think the `tf_prefix` param works for the joint\_state\_publisher so the TF frame name may be slightly different. You can try this first and see if it works.
content.html:
Ok then in that case the fix should be simple. Previously, in the localization_example.launch , the static TFs are published via

<!-- Publishes static transforms (gps, imu, cameras, etc) to /tf -->
  <node ns="wamv" pkg="robot_state_publisher" type="robot_state_publisher" name="rob_st_pub">
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="wamv" />
  </node>

However, as seen in pull request 216, revolute joints are being used instead of fixed joints. The robot_state_publisher can only publish static joint TF to my knowledge. As such, you will need to use the joint_state_publisher as well to get the GPS as IMU TFs to be published. You can try this instead:

‌

‌

<!-- Publishes fixed joint static transforms (cameras, lidars, etc) to /tf -->
  <node ns="wamv" pkg="robot_state_publisher" type="robot_state_publisher" name="rob_st_pub">
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="wamv" />
  </node>

<!-- Publishes revolute joint static transforms (gps and imu) to /tf -->
    <node name="joint_state_publisher" pkg="joint_state_publisher" type="joint_state_publisher" output="screen">
      <param name="gui" value="false" />
    </node>

‌

I don’t think the tf_prefix param works for the joint_state_publisher so the TF frame name may be slightly different. You can try this first and see if it works.

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
I tried to add the `joint_state_publisher` to the` localization_example.launch` file, I still get the same warning and a new error stating that the `joint_state_publisher-2` process has died. This is the output when running the localization\_example while running `roscore `and `roslaunch vrx_gazebo sandisland.launch urdf:=$HOME/my_wamv/my_wamv.urdf`:

```
$ roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization_example.launch

Press Ctrl-C to interrupt
Done checking log file disk usage. Usage is <1GB.

started roslaunch server http://markus-MacBookPro:46215/

SUMMARY
========

PARAMETERS
 * /joint_state_publisher/gui: False
 * /rosdistro: melodic
 * /rosversion: 1.14.5
 * /wamv/rob_st_pub/tf_prefix: wamv
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/base_link_frame: wamv/base_link
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/frequency: 60
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/imu0: /wamv/sensors/imu...
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/imu0_config: [False, False, Fa...
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/imu0_differential: False
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/imu0_remove_gravitational_acceleration: True
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/map_frame: map
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/odom0: /wamv/robot_local...
 * /wamv/robot_localization/ekf_localization/odom0_config: [True, True, True...

This is the output when running the localization_example while running roscoreand roslaunch vrx_gazebo sandisland.launch urdf:=$HOME/my_wamv/my_wamv.urdf:

issue.title: When running RVIZ tutorial, there is an issue with the lidar

content.raw:
As seen in your logs, the error says: `RuntimeError: The robot_description parameter is required and not set.` This is because the parameter is specified under the `wamv` namespace but the joint state publisher is running in the global namespace. There was a typo in the original answer which missed this namespace, try this instead with the `wamv` namespace:

```
<!-- Publishes fixed joint static transforms (cameras, lidars, etc) to /tf -->
  <node ns="wamv" pkg="robot_state_publisher" type="robot_state_publisher" name="rob_st_pub">
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="wamv" />
  </node>

<!-- Publishes revolute joint static transforms (gps and imu) to /tf -->
    <node ns="wamv" name="joint_state_publisher" pkg="joint_state_publisher" type="joint_state_publisher" output="screen">
      <param name="gui" value="false" />
    </node>
```

‌
content.html:
As seen in your logs, the error says: RuntimeError: The robot_description parameter is required and not set. This is because the parameter is specified under the wamv namespace but the joint state publisher is running in the global namespace. There was a typo in the original answer which missed this namespace, try this instead with the wamv namespace:

<!-- Publishes fixed joint static transforms (cameras, lidars, etc) to /tf -->
  <node ns="wamv" pkg="robot_state_publisher" type="robot_state_publisher" name="rob_st_pub">
    <param name="tf_prefix" value="wamv" />
  </node>

<!-- Publishes revolute joint static transforms (gps and imu) to /tf -->
    <node ns="wamv" name="joint_state_publisher" pkg="joint_state_publisher" type="joint_state_publisher" output="screen">
      <param name="gui" value="false" />
    </node>

‌
